ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: learned to look at disease with much greater complexity and depth, with the pleasure of having Dr. Boulpaep's approachable and understandable teaching style
I learned valuable concepts in human physiology, ranging from relevant gene mutations to their associated diseases and the mechanisms by which they cause the diseases.

I learned to understand gross physiology by considering molecular mechanisms and how individual protein players can interact to yield pathophysiology. I also learned to read papers from clinical studies and received a cursory introduction to differentials that can be applied to aid in diagnosis.
Learned about different channels, pumps, and transporters and how mutant versions of these can lead to different diseases
I learned how to look at diseases by understanding its molecular machines
Learned about human physiological systems and the molecular basis of diseases.
I learned physiology through a host of different diseases that affect systems like the liver, kidney, respiratory system, brain and others.

This class was great. It was so interesting to learn about human diseases and the genetic mutations that cause them. Professor Boulpaep did a great job at giving the full picture from the macroscopic disease phenotype to the microscopic mutated proteins.
I learned A LOT in this class. It really summarized and encompassed a lot of themes I had learned in other MCDB classes.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Excellent class, wouldnt change a thing

Strengths: the lecture slides are very well-organized and helpful for understanding the material, and the professor and TA were very helpful with explaining difficult concepts and answering any questions that students have.

The course is well organized (albeit a bit text heavy at times) because of Dr. Boulpaep's organizational skills. We didn't get any feedback on the reading responses or practice exam questions, both of which would have been nice.

Strengths: powerpoint, live virtual lectures

Weaknesses: professor lacked technology knowledge and often relied on the TA for such matters but they were often late
I love Professor Boulpaep. He was very understanding and his lecture slides contained all the relevant information which helped with my review and understanding
The lecture slides we well put together and helped with studying. Sometimes the lectures went too long.

This course was engaging in that each lecture was presented as a case study. I liked understanding the context of physiology in different disease states, which made the class really interesting! We also engaged with several papers throughout the course. 

Improvement: I would have appreciated having feedback on my assignments.
At times, the meat of the lecture felt a bit rushed given that Professor Boulpaep goes over the clinical aspects before jumping into the molecular part of the lecture.
I like the clinical aspect but I think. The lecture slides could be structured to be more engaging.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Not much was different except for the availability of recorded lectures which made it much easier to go back and review

Dr. Boulpaep recorded each lecture, but did not record the live discussions for each of the papers. I found that this was accommodating for everyone with varied schedules because we had the flexibility of attending if we could, but not having to stress if we could not.
TA office hours online were very helpful and were held frequently.

I appreciated the structure of the course. Disease states that seemed similar to one another or involved similar systems were presented together, which helped me to track the progression of the course.
I don't feel there were any practices specifically geared toward covid learning aside from recorded Zoom lectures.
Recorded lectures worked well.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes

I would recommend this course to any student interested in human physiology! I really liked learning about the clinical cases, which helped me better understand the cellular pathologies and mechanisms and how they contribute to diseases.
If you are looking for an upper division elective to fulfill your MCDB requirement, this class is pretty chill, but the grading could end up being kind of harsh.
If anyone is going to take this course it is most likely because of major requirements. It satisfies the MCDB upper elective requirement, but any other course would be fine.
Yes I would recommend this to anyone studying biological sciences.
Yes absolutely
Yes if youre premed take it!
Yes, the course is graded fairly and helps to connect your learning in biology.
Yes! Especially if you are interested in studying medicine. This course covers a lot of material but is manageable if you review consistently.

Yes, this class is wonderful. The material is super interesting and Professor Boulpaep is very passionate about his work. Although the required course work is very low (five 1-2 page papers, a midterm, & a final) the course does require a fair amount of outside studying in preparation for the exams given that there is a lot of material covered in each lecture. Professor Boulpaep's slides, however, are very detailed and are incredibly useful when studying for exams.
Yes. It was interesting.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: The lectures were live and virtual, but recordings were uploaded on Box for students who could not attend the live lectures and/or preferred to watch the lectures asynchronously.
Lectures were mostly recorded
n/a
also recorded
Discussions as well.
N/A
I attended live virtual lectures but also re-watched all of the lecture recordings when preparing for exams. I found it extremely helpful to have the recorded lectures.
Na
